text: The 1987 INF, as its name suggests, concerned intermediate nuclear forces with ranges between 300 and 3,000 miles. Bush and Gorbachev made separate moves to restrict TNWs in 1991.
author: TimFernholz

text: This treaty doesn't concern tactical nukes, so I'm not sure what you're on about? Also the US removed most of its TNWs from Europe in 1991...
author: TimFernholz

text: Leaving the treaty leaves NATO and the US split on how to respond. NATO's statement pointedly calls for negotiations and new arms controls, something the US doesn't seem to have the appetite for.
author: TimFernholz

text: The really loser here is arms control writ large—that international treaties can restrain the world-ending class of weapons developed by humanity for their own good.
author: TimFernholz

text: The elephant in the room is China, which has its own medium range nuclear missiles and isn’t constrained by the treaty. Both the US and Russia are concerned about this, and any future arms control agreement will need the “third power.”
author: TimFernholz

text: under Trump and Bolton, the likelier option is that more focus will go toward building out new middle-range nuclear missiles (perhaps cruise missiles or sea-launched) to compete with Russia—that is, a new nuclear arms race.
author: TimFernholz

text: What will the US do? One option is trying to push new missile defense systems in Europe to defend against middle-range nukes, with the hope that Russia will halt its missile deployments in exchange for an end to the defense system.
author: TimFernholz

text: What now? Don’t hold your breathe on Putin ditching his missiles and giving in with US global influence at a nadir under Trump.
author: TimFernholz

text: Fixing it with the old military options won’t exactly be easy, as this article notes  https://www.armscontrolwonk.com/archive/1202903/responding-to-the-inf-treaty-violation/ …
author: TimFernholz

text: Leaving INF is seen as a win for Putin—it splits the US and NATO countries who don’t want US nukes in their backyards. Moscow will have an easier time of deploying new missiles than Washington, and blaming the US for leaving the treaty
author: TimFernholz

text: Under Putin, Russia began violating the treaty around 2014, building and testing a new series of medium range missiles. Many urged Obama, then president, to leave the treaty, but European allies feared a resulting arms race.
author: TimFernholz

text: ...but Russia thinks it does, because of land threats from Europe. Under INF, US and Russian ground-based nuclear missiles were pulled out of Europe, reducing Cold War tensions.
author: TimFernholz

text: This treaty helped end the Cold War with limits ground-based medium range nuclear missiles—those that can fly between 300 and 3,400 miles. The US doesn’t really need those thanks to its unique borders...
author: TimFernholz
